awd_titl_txt: Robotics Science and Systems 2019 Meet the Women in Robotics Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a large disparity in the gender of researchers in robotics.  As the field of robotics becomes more integrated in every aspect of our society it is important that there be more women roboticists. This award helps US graduate students travel to attend the Women in Robotics workshop that will take place at the Robotics Science and Systems conference.    This workshop will highlight the work of important female roboticists and by raising their visibility hopefully encourage more women to pursue robotics research.

Robots are anticipated to be an integral part of meeting societal needs in domains like healthcare, space exploration, and education. To meet the growing demand for robotics technologies in these domains, the pool of capable roboticists will need to grow in kind. However, the number of female roboticists entering the field continues to notably lag behind male counterparts. This gender disparity presents a significant hurdle for adequately meeting the demand for experienced robot scientists. The Meet the Women in Robotics Workshop (WiRW) is focused on reducing the gender gap in the robotics domain by providing an opportunity to feature the work of prominent female roboticists. The fifth Meet the Women in Robotics Workshop (WiRW) aims to (1) raise the visibility of women in robotics, (2) strengthen the community of female roboticists and provide an opportunity for networking, and (3) connect junior robotics researchers to senior mentors in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Broader impacts

Robots are anticipated to be an integral part of meeting societal needs in a variety of domains including healthcare, space exploration, and education in the near future. To meet the growing demand for robots and robotics technologies, the pool of capable roboticists will need to grow in kind. However, although the number of roboticists in academia and industry is growing, the number of female roboticists entering the field continues to lag behind male counterparts. 

The purpose of the Fifth Meet the Women in Robotics Workshop (WiRW) was to help reduce the gender gap in the robotics research community by providing an opportunity to feature the work of prominent female roboticists while mentoring young female robot scientists entering the field. Held on June 23, 2019 at the University of Freiburg, Germany, the Fifth Meet the Women in Robotics Workshop was held in order to:

  • Raise the visibility of women in robotics research by presenting invited talks from women leaders in their subfields, thus demonstrating that women can and do play an important role in the robotics community. 

  • Strengthen the community by bringing together women from various disciplines and provide opportunities for networking across disciplines and stages of careers. 

  • Connect junior female robotics researchers to senior mentors in the field. 

  • Highlight the work (selected by peer-review) of junior researchers in the field of robotics (undergraduate, graduate students, and postdocs) in two poster sessions. 

  • Ultimately, increase the exposure of women in robotics to help close the gender gap in the broader robotics community. 

 

To meet these goals, the program included a variety of opportunities to feature the work of female roboticists and encourage networking among the community. The 2019 Meet the WiRW was a mixed-audience, female-only presenter event that featured a variety of scientific talks, and engaging activities to achieve our goals. The workshop included a keynote presentation, invited career talks, a panel of academic researchers and industry representatives discussing professional issues and how they have successfully navigated them (e.g., changing advisers, negotiating salaries), mentor-mentee introduction activities, two junior researcher poster sessions, and networking breaks. 

 

 

Intellectual Merit

With the generous support of our sponsors, we were able to provide funding for 23 students to attend the workshop. Table 1 provides examples of presented poster topics. 

 

 

  • Presenter                                                                    

Theresa Kessler    

Jana Pavlasek

Xela Indurkhya

Ziggy O'Reilly 

Padmaja Vivek Kulkarni

Bernadette Bucher 

Carolyn Matl

Gilwoo Lee

 

  • Topic

Neurological and Physiological correlates of trust in robots

Scene understanding using part-based object Affordances

In the wild child-robot interaction

Socially assistive robotics 

Bi-manual teleoperation Popov-Vereshchagin hybrid dynamics

Curiosity as an exploration policy in reinforcement learning

Robotic liquid perception via haptic sensing

Bayesian policy optimization for model uncertainty 

 

  • University

University of Central Florida

University of Michigan

Tokyo Institute of Agriculture and Technology

University of  Western Australia

University of Bonn

University of Pennsylvania

University of California Berkeley

University of Washington

 

Our participants (students, speakers, panelists, and organizers) represented 37 different universities and organizations across 11 countries, and presented 8 technical talks, 1 panel, and 34 poster presentations. The funding raised for the workshop was used to provide travel awards to junior female robotics researchers to present their research in one of two poster presentation sessions. Applicants for travel awards submitted extended research abstracts to the organizing team. The organizing team then scored their abstracts for technical merit. In total, we hosted 34 posters from junior female robotics researchers across the two sessions. 

Outcomes

It is clear that support from our sponsors and conference leadership has helped us to maintain the momentum and numerous successes of the program established over the last five years. Several of our travel award alumni presented at other R:SS workshops and in the full conference in 2019, and are now long term members of the R:SS community. In 2020, we transitioned to a new opportunity which highlights the successes of this program, advancing our desire to advocate for intersectional forms of diversity in the robotics community. We recognize that diversity includes the intersection of multiple identities, and that among the robotics and computer science communities, women are underrepresented, but women of color are even more so.  After five successful Women in Robotics Workshops, the organizers for the 2020 workshop have merged the WiRW with the Inclusion @ R:SS Program, started by Dr. Kress-Gazit (R:SS President, Cornell University) in 2018.
